text:
Just returned from a. 10 day trip.

Naples - stayed fairly local in town. Was very happy to see the local flair. Easy to get around by foot or metro. Streets were a little dirty but whatever - it’s a city and I’m from NYC.

Took a day trip booked through hotel to Positano and spent 3 hours on beach then off to Sorrento for an hour.

Booked ferry through direct ferries to Capri. Spend the day walking around and sitting on beach. Very touristy area. High end shops. Reminded me of Rodeo Drive and 5th avenue. Did NOT go to other side where grotto kids were fine not seeing this.

Day trip to Pompeii and Mt Vesuvius for small group guided tour. Was amazing. Our tour guide was fabulous. Learned so much.

the FOOD IN NAPLES WAS THE ABSOLUTE BEST. And reasonably priced.

Euro rail to Rome
Pantheon - amazing but quick
Colosseum and Vatican small group guided tours. FANTASTIC. Took metro here as well. LOTS of walking.
Rode bikes through Villa Borghese
Took bus to walk around Trastavere

Euro rail to Venice. So charming and quaint.
More expensive and sisnt find the food outstanding and yet being in Naples and Rome. Was able to see everything in 1.5 days

My kids wore Birks. They were fine. I wore hey dudes and I was fine.

Rely on your front desk staff. They are very helpful and speak English. Walk randomly to local spots.

Metro was safe during day.
Bus was easy accepts Apple Pay

text: Question about SIM cards. If I purchase a sim card in Paris will it work in Italy? Or will I need to purchase one in both countries. Sim sees more advantageous then my phone plan.

comments.comment_text: No, you will need a different one for Italy
U can get esim card that works in all of Europe, we used Nomad (data only)
You can buy an esim from flyesim app

Some works in other EU countries,some don’t

I bought lycamobile in Portugal…it worked in Spain and France but didn’t work in Belgium…it works but no data in Germany…
Get an esim from flyesim app
Use Airalo and buy a regional plan. It should work in all of Europe.
Orange SIM will work in both

I've always only bought one SIM while traveling in Europe and never once had any issues moving from country to country. From Paris, use Orange. Find a store and go inside and they will get you going. Make sure you have your passport ready, they may ask for it. If you have a newer phone like the IPHONE 14, they'll install an ESIM if it's an older phone, they will install a SIM. Both work. I once used orange in 5 countries on the same trip. Including Russia.
In EU countries there are no more roaming
A SIM card from France will work in Italy. We found orange to be the best for us.
esim is better
Orange SIM Card works in Spain, France, Italy, Austria and Germany

WhatsApp!!!!!
Call, text, FaceTime. No charge.
Is buying a “throw away” phone a good idea? Read prior postings of just buying 2 cells for Italy and toss when leaving … maybe under $50 or so? I have ATT

European sim cards work all over Europe. You could just encounter some limitations on amount of data traffic you have available when you go abroad of the country where you bought the SIM.

For example I have my Italian SIM that has 50GB included, but when I travel in Europe I can use just 7GB. I don't know how is with french SIMs

So if you use lots of data traffic consider buying another SIM card in Italy, there are cheap companies like Iliad that work smooth and are less than 10 euros for a month with plenty of data traffic included
I purchased mine on Amazon from Three UK, from Canada. I put the SIM card in as soon as we touched down in Frankfurt. It’s been great! Had service within about 5 minutes.
If u get a Euro one. I got one that worked in Germany, Italy and Greece

Orange works very well in every country we have traveled too including Bulgaria and Romania
Have fun!
I have a Vodafone Italy SIM card, can I use it in Portugal?
All EU cards will work in any EU country the same.
Yes it will!
Here in EU we can use the same SIM, zero problems, zero issues.

Majority of SIMs that are for visitors ie pay as you go. Good for a month or so are Good for ALL of EU.
I’ve never had not that wasn’t.
Airalo regional card works throughout France and Italy

text:
It was our family’s first time travelling to Rome and this group has helped us a lot in planning, so I am coming back in this group with recommendation.

We had jet lag so we woke up pretty early, rented two lime scooters from Uber and planned a route around few of the major attractions just to take pictures. We started around 7:30am and endedआणखी around 9am. Most of these sites had no one around or very little people, it was awesome to avoid the crowds.

Some of the attractions we got to see not in order:
Ponte Sisto
Area Sacra Di Largo Argentina
Monument to Victor Emmanuel II
Roman Forum
Tabularium
Coliseum
Fontana Di Trevi (this was the busiest site but even then we were able to find a good spot and get a good shot with not many people around)
Spanish steps
River Tiber
Corte Suprema di Cassazione
Castes Sant’Angelo

I’d says early morning with the scooter is much better since the streets are quite empty too and we were able to whiz around safely. I’d say from 8:30 we started to see some people and streets are busier with cars and buses.

text: Heading to Messiina ( Sicily) as a port stop on a cruise in Sept We have approximately 5 hours anyone have a good local tour company to suggest?
Is it better to stay in hotels or air bnb’s for two people in Italy?

comments.comment_text: Either

I prefer Airbnb’s for a couple reasons. I like that they have kitchens and I always get one with a washer machine so that I can do Landry especially for the longer length trips. I also like the local experience of living like a local. You can find some really charming airbnbs and really get a feel of what it would be like if you lived there.

The only downside we dont like about AirBnBs if ur doing like 2-3 day stays in different places, is they usually have a 3-6pm checkin with no where to store your bags and then a 10am check out. Compared to hotels where they are more accommodating.
Yes! All of the above 🥰
I like airbnb but for this trip I need to stay at a hotel to be able to ask the front desk questions lol
I loved the three airbnbs I used
Airbnbs 100%!
We loved our airbnbs and Vrbos
Depending on the travel conditions. Longer stay in one location more than a week, I consider an apartment rental.
Hotels

We are going next summer. We are going on a cruise from Barcelona to Rome, and then staying in Praiano for 7 nights. We rented VRBOs in all three places. Took a lot of time reading reviews. We wanted washer/dryer and good AC. We have learned to like Airbnb/VRBO because we like having a little living area to relax in an drink our coffee too. This will be our first time in Europe, so I hope the experiences in these rentals are as good as places we have traveled in the states. So far the hosts seem even more accommodating!

Airbnb because you can live like a local. Shop, cook and do washing. Stayed in amazing places throughout Italy which made our trip so memorable.
I did both

That depends on what you feel most comfortable in. Personally we like hotels. When on vacation I don’t want to bother doing anything as far as needing a kitchen. We like a nice room, house keeping and a place to wake up have breakfast waiting for us and take off for a full day of sightseeing. Return late afternoon to a clean room , rest and go out to dinner. text:
I’m sorry if this sounds silly..
But has anyone been to Florence but not super keen on visiting museums? (I know right.. then it’s like, why go to hometown of Sandra/Leonardo/Michelangelo etc etc).

Did anyone prefer other sites over museums?

comments.comment_text:
My favorite Florence memory was climbing up to the top of that dome, and looking out the little windows at the top.

Don’t get me wrong, David was awesome, and I’ll go see David again one day, but the little tiny window that I was looking out of made me think about the fact that I was the only person on earth that had that exact view at that exact moment. I think it was one of those little holes near the top of the dome that you can see in this photo.

￼ I find stuff Like that as inspiring as some of the things I see in museums. Although I do love both. Another one of my favorite things to do in any city is to just walk around randomly. No maps, just walking down the street turning right or left. Just following whatever looks interesting.

We made it a point to see all three David's, which provided for different excursions. One to just wander the streets. One to hike up to Piazzale Michaelangelo and take in the views. And one to go to a museum and have an early start to the day. The first and last could be coupled, but wandering through the streets with the only goal being to get to dinner the first evening and happening upon Piazza della Signoria as it started the transition to night was a great start to our visit.
Boboli garden!
Ya I didn’t go to any museums there except I ran in to the Accademia to see the david. Saw the duomo and walked around the squares then spent a lot of time shopping lol

Go at your own pace, don't feel pressured to do those things if you find other things you'd like to do instead, I reckon!
Not a big fan of memuseums or churches, they all star to look the same soon. Enjoy wondering the streets, getting lost, have coffee, gelato breaks

I always loved the museums & galleries & visited them, including the churches. But, there is plenty of fun to be had in Florence too.... Try the motorbikes tour of the local vineyards & wineries, so much fun! Also, the day tours of Tuscany to Siena & San Gimengano & Olive Oil presses, shopping etc.
Bike tour, food tour, shopping, eating and drinking and just enjoying the Italian culture, that’s what we did!

It makes it interesting for kids and Adults.

We have family just outside Firenze, so on my first trip as a 9-year-old, we visited Leonardo’s birthplace in Anchiano, about a km from Vinci. Granted in those days (1960) it was just an ancient farmhouse at the top of a dirt road. (It’s quite built up now.) But in Vinci there is a Leonardo museum displaying models of his many inventions, which could appeal to a 9-year-old. A bit of history would be helpful, but Leonardo was such a visionary in many areas that a kid could pick any number of topics and write about him in school. I’m 72 now and I never miss a chance to visit Anchiano or Vinci. 🙂

Let's just say, I am heading back to Rome next year and doing a day trip back to Florence.

I live near the MET and 10 blocks from MOMA and I have only been to special exhibits that appeal to me. For years, I never told anybody, including about Florence! Not being interested in museums doesn’t make you any less than somebody else. And, by the way, it is your vacation! Personally, I preferred spending the day in the piazzas, having espresso and shopping! I must admit, though I have seen the David every time. text:
Our trip is in six weeks and I'm trying not to worry but the trains on the first day are keeping me awake! I have booked other trains for during the trip but the day we arrive at the airport we need to take three well timed trains.
Our plane is supposed to land at 745am and then we have to get through airport/passport control etc
FCO-Roma termini (open tickets purchased)
Roma Termini to napoli centrale (we intend on the Frecciarossa)
Napoli Garibaldi to pompei (yes we are staying there, not a day trip) and intended on the Campania Express. (but it only leaves at 1126am or 226pm
What are the chances we can get an available business class seat on Frecciarrosa if I purchase that day?
I know some people say just to get regional train from naples to pompei but with backpacks and luggage im nervous about that particular train and keeping everything safe when its so crowded


should i purchase a freccciarrosa ticket now and wing it from there?
Any kind advice is most welcome. Im not stubborn about what we do, i just want to get to the hotel (with our carryon, and we are carrying all our things passports etc) in one piece.
It seems too difficult to purchase tickets in advance relying on everything to fall into place.

comments.comment_text:
I’m not sure why everyone would asume the regional train would be more pick pocket risk that a tourist train. But also assume tourists are the main target for pick pockets.

We got both - didn’t see pickpockets on either but the Campania express is more modern and quicker

I’d book your train tickets at 2:26.
Take the Leonardo Express to Roma Termini.

Store your bag at Stow Your Bags for a few hours.

https://
www.stowyourbags
.com/en/shop/
rome/
luggage-storage-
termini-train-s
tation-via-mars
ala/
HOW TO ARRIVE:
At Termini train station take the exit on the right toward Via Marsala. Go right for a few steps, than turn left onto Via Milazzo. You will find us at number 20A on the left side.
KEY INFO: FROM 1,99€ PER LOCKER | 100% SAFE AND INSURED | 1 MINUTE FROM TERMINI STATION

Go get some lunch and a gelato and walk around rome for a couple hours.
Then go back to the train station, get your bags, and catch your train to Naples.
I’ve been here for 3/5 days have just kept a hold of my bag and been fine !
Why would you go for a business class on frecciarossa?
I would say yes because around 15th of September tourist season is ending. But time seem a bit stretched to me. Roma Napoli is around 2 hours if I remember correctly

I would hirer a driver from Naples to Pompei. We only paid 100 euros from sorrento to Naples and it was well worth it. Depending on the amount of luggage you have the regional or local trains do t have a lot of room.

We did good seats on the fast train from Rome to Naples because there was a family pack that was cheap. I booked that in advance. I wish we could have done that everywhere !!!
I didn’t see a nice fast train to Pompeii from Naples so went downstairs to the train that runs from Naples to Sorrento and it ran pretty frequently. Just bought the tickets at the station for this one. It’s definitely more crowded and difficult to find seats together and deal with luggage but it was doable. We DID see a guy pickpocketed on this train on the way back another day - it’s so crowded you just have to protect your things really well.
We got the local train Naples to Pompeii with luggage and had no problems.

Think the 'hysteria' about pickpockets is blown out of all proportion I have travelled on trains alone in my 70s and i havent had any incidents just make sure you are aware at all times im loving it! so easy to book trains here and train from pisa to florence had ample room for everyones bags really geared to tourists easy to buy tickets too at station
There is a new train connection from FCO to Napoli!!!!!
Look at rome2rio.com, there are tons of options. There are also tons of trains. If it were me, and I was that concerned, I would hire a driver from Staples to Palmbay. You can use sun transfers.com.

You’re also making yourself crazy over some thing you have no control over. The time it takes to get through customs could be 40 minutes or three hours depending on how many planes came in and how efficient the transportation people are at that time. The train ride from Rome to Naples is under two hours, so just get the first available train and be done with it.

Would you consider a private driver taking you from Napoli Centrale to your hotel in Pompeii? You can get the Leonardo Express from airport to Roma Centrale. I pre-booked mine with a time but the time doesn’t print on the ticket, you just jump on the next available train. I would pre book the Frecciarossa via Trenitalia before you go. Just give yourself plenty of time, even if you need to wait a bit at Roma Centrale. They have an upper level with cafes and restaurants where you can wait. Re: business…do it!! I upgraded a few train trips to Business and I thought it was great, and obviously better. You get snacks and drinks too. There was much more room for luggage making it easier to keep it near you even if you had big bags. If you want to get a driver from Naples, I recommend Rainbow Limos. I found them online via many good reviews, and they lived up to them. Exceptional service and communicators. They will meet you on the platform with your name on a sign. I know a car service will obvs be more expensive than a driver but you will be thanking yourself after a flight + trains!! https://
www.rainbowlimos
.com/

We did this - except went all the way to Sorrento. FCO at that time (7:30 am) on our arrival day was very empty, and we walked right through passport control. Termini was no problem either. Napoli Centrale to Campagna Express - we had to run! I knew it was downstairs and just kept following signs for Circumvesuvania
. I did not find it well marked for Campagna Express. We finally asked someone who worked there, and they were helpful. The good thing is on Campagna Express they check your tickets before you get on, so as long as you are in that line it won’t leave without you.

First class was really was comfortable
Booked in advance

If you miss the 2nd Campania Express.
Then just take the Circumvesuviana
. It’s fine, we did it with carryons and backpacks to Sorrento. Yes, it was crowded, we chose to stand at the back of the car we were out of the way etc and no one moving behind us.

We were going to take the Campania Express but it would have been a 2 hour wait, so just took the Circumvesuviana
.
Worry less, just enjoy, whatever train you get will be fine.
I’d take a cab, honestly after an overnight trip, three more transfers will be exhausting
The trains aren't your problem... they run on time. It's making your connecting flight, delays, flight cancelations, etc.

Wait. I’m going in 6 weeks too but to Napoli to Sorrento, do we have to buy train tickets in advance?
Same question regarding taking the Ferry from Napoli to Sorrento?
If you havent booked them yet, the other high speee train company offers a full service. Italotreno. They do Rome termin- Napoli Afragola by train then they have a bus service directly to pompei...

I just did this from Rome to Sorrento. I didn’t pre book anything because I didn’t know how long it would take to get through customs (which took 5 minutes!). Just went to the train station and bought a ticket to the fast train and I was able to get business class. Then when I got to Naples I bought a ticket to Sorrento on circumvesuviana
. It was relatively easier than people made it sound. I was traveling with my 17 year old son. In the end I was glad I saved $140 euros from having to hire a private driver to go from Naples to Sorrento. On the way back, I did something completely different because I was traveling back on a Sunday and the earliest train out of Sorrento to Naples was 10:20. I got this advice from two Australian women that were seasoned travelers that I met while I was in Sorrento. I took a “shuttle bus” from Sorrento (picks you up a train station) and drops you off at Naples airport. Then I took a shared taxi (5 euro/piece) from airport to Naples train station. Easy and cheap. Shuttle is $10 euro/
pp and it’s a nice,comfortable air conditioned bus. ☺️
Rent a car from airport, drive to Naples AP drop it off, take taxi to Pompeii, my friend Salvatore Fossa will be glad to pick you up from the car rental lot in Naples, 1 block from the AP.

In the FCO airport… where is the train station? After we go through customs, where do we go next?? We will be taking a train to Naples.

Also, since I don’t know if the flight will be on time, can I reserve a train ticket for any time, or does it have to be at a specific time?? ￼

The pickpockets concerns make me equally chuckle and sigh of despair 😩 but trains in Italy can be notoriously a pain so ,if you are carrying a lot of luggage and have a hard stop with the last train not running past a certain time, I would definitely want to avoid the risk of being stuck without plan B. I don’t have details of a private driver, but since the tariffs of taxis in Napoli are fixed for certain routes including Pompeii, you can always jump on a cab if you arrive at the station after the last regional train has left (it’s not cheap though, something like €100).
Having said this, you have plenty of time for all connections and Frecciarossa trains tend to run on time and are fast, so you should be ok. The regional train is less reliable…

(From US) Do you Need to have an international drivers license to drive a Vespa? We booked a Vespa tour in Rome, and the paperwork online only says must have a drivers license.

* through a guided tour booked with the company “get your guide”

comments.comment_text: I believe you need an international driver’s license.
Yep
Do you need a motorcycle endorsement?

We didn’t need one for a 4wheeler tour on etna but we weren’t really riding in streets except for a short distance. I would assume for Vespa tour it would be in your best interest to have one just in case!
Yes.
Yes, it couldn't hurt to have an international driver's license anyway. The cost to get one is minimal.

Yes, you need an IDP to ride a Vespa (as the driver). Above 150cc (iirc), you also need a motorcycle endorsement on the IDP.

Most rental sites don't require you to have the IDP for the rental, but the law requires you to have one on you while riding.
I believe you do. My husband went to AAA and he said it took maybe 10 minutes. Super easy
Make sure your insurance covers you for this ride🌻
We're renting a vespa in Lake Como and got the international driving permit from AAA for $20.

text:
We'll be visiting Italy for about 9 days and then up to Germany for 20 days. Our schedule is flexible. My current plan is to fly into Rome April 25, and then leave Venice to head to Munich around May 4. I would have preferred to visit Germany first and end in Italy, but my thoughts are that the weather will be better in Germany if we wait a littleआणखी longer, and that the crowds in Italy may be a little less if we go a little earlier. Is this correct, or is there even much difference in crowds at end of April/first week of May?
It's been 20 years since I was there and my family has never been so we'll be visiting the usual places this trip. Rome, Cinque Terre, Florence, Venice, and Tuscany. I wish I could do an off the beaten path itinerary to avoid crowds but that's not in the cards this time. Anyone that has visited these areas at this time, is this a good time to go or should I adjust our dates/plan? I definitely do NOT want to go in summer.

comments.comment_text: You definitely are going during low season. It will be a bit chilly then. Sounds like a wonderful family trip!
The 25th of April is national holiday as well as the first of May, in between there is a weekend. Likely a lot of people will be moving around.

I’m almost doing the same, Italy first and Germany second but a couple of weeks later. I like to do Germany second so I can fill my suitcase full of treats to take home!! I might have a black Licorice addiction 😉.

This spring in Italy, it was cool and rainy right into June. A different story in 2022. We were in Rome May 19 for a tennis tournament, and we couldn't believe how crowded the usual spots were. Fortunately, we have been to them all, so we found a few new distractions. Probably safer to go a little earlier and take your chances on the weather.

As someone already reported, Italy will be experiencing an overall vacation week between April 25 and May 1st. Don't expect to find shops/museums closed, just hige crowds everywhere.
On the contrary, Germany has Whitsun later in May (which is not observed in Italy)

text:
Travelling to Venice from Ravenna post-cruise.

1. Would you recommend the Frecciarossa train over the second option?

2. We are planning to get a hotel near the airport as we fly out early the next day. Wouldआणखी we be better off taking the train into Mestre and getting then getting to our hotel from there, or taking the train into the Santa Lucia station and backtracking to the airport? Can we take a train from there to the airport?

3. I noticed on the Trainline app I can book business class but I couldn’t on the Omio app, it only showed 2nd class for the same trip. I couldn’t get the Trenitalia website to work at all. Any idea why this would be? Leaning towards using Trainline to book business class.

Thanks! ☺️

comments.comment_text: We used Trainline quite a bit and it was great!

I would go to Mestre and drop your luggage off at your hotel. Venice is not somewhere you want to try and lug around any luggage. Then go back to mestre and take the train to Santa Lucia.

For the day of your flight you can take the public bus. There may be one close to your hotel but one runs to and from mestre multiple times a day. Your hotel should be able to help you figure out which bus to take.
Book italo trains, privately owned and better.

Both options are not the best, seeing the time it’s probably the option Ravenna-Bologna
-Venezia, it’s faster and cheaper do Ravenna-Ferrara
-Bologna. The train from Ravenna to Bologna and from Ravenna to Ferrara are regional, and there is only second class, that may be the reason why you can’t book business class for the entire trip. Also, Italo has no trains going through the station in Ravenna, your only option from there is Trenitalia

Use Trenitalia’s official app or website.
Frecciarossa is the fastest high speed train available. It will save you precious time
Following because I’m struggling with the Trenitalia app/website
Get the cheaper one

Frecciarossa is a fast train, they make stops in the main train stations, for example Santa Maria Novella in Florence and Regionale and interegionale thet stop in each main little town, and sometimes they don't get to the main stations, that would make their last stop in the second main station, and then you would have to take another train. That's how they work.

They both take the same length of time.... So why would you get the more expensive one? 🤔. There is very little difference between Class 1 and Class 2 in the trains - Its not like a flight. You get a little more room, little more luggage space, less tourists.

Please don’t visit/
stay in 8 cities in 12 days. You will spend too much of your trip traveling between cities, checking in and out, packing and waiting on transportation. 3 cities at the most. Rome, Florence, Venice would be nice. Verona and Pisa are just day trips from Venice and Florence.
Depends on you. Think of it as a land cruise. See all the places, and come back and stay at your favorites.
Deborah Fagan
Too much travel for me. I’d stay in 3 cities.
Trying to see too much IMO. Perhaps drop Naples and Milan.
Way too much for 12 days. You will spend most of your time traveling between cities and checking in and out of hotels.

Verona Saccardi hotel and spa. Absolutely great hotel. Bologna i stayed in Hotel Atlantic. Close to train station, old town and everything you need to see, eat and shop. Charming old small hotel with the best service and ok breakfast to a good prize.

We did it this July by our own car from Athens. The same cities except of Milan . It is some Kms out of our way . We did it in 12 days . We stayed 2 nights in every city . It was a bit tiring due to the heat waves but we made it through.
Also the fact that we had our own can made us insecure. We were afraid of being stolen or had an unpredictable incident . Everything went fine but next time we may rend a car instead. It’s better .

Are you the type of person who needs to be on the go everyday? If yes, then it's great for you. You won't even need to unpack. You are probably just bringing a carry on an a backpack. If you are not the type of traveler then this is a very tough schedule.

eh...skip milan unless you like $150 shirts and getting dirty looks from fashionistas...
had a cool china town
We are in Como now and its beautiful and amazing

Florence,la speiza, montorosso, SML and pisa

This year we are doing naples, cassino, salerno, sorrento 13 nights
3 places, 4 max! You want time to look around and enjoy what each city has to offer, not be constantly repacking and running to the train station or getting right on the road!
12 days its a joke :)

We went for 12 days and did Rome, Assisi, the Amalfi coast, and flew to Malta. Spent about three days everywhere.

And I felt like it was ambitious.

3 in Rome
3 in Florence
Day tour to Pisa from Florence

i would skip Milan (or even Pisa and add it to Verona or Bologna)
Doesn't matter. You will be so tired you will not even notice. 10 cities in 12 days is not travel its selfies marathon.

Fly into Milan, Fly out of Rome
Are you driving ?

2nd Night Venice
Drive through Tuscany to Pisa. Move on to Florence
3rd & 4th night

6th in Naples
Almafi .. to Sorrento

and
ARRIVADERCI

Stay in those cities, use Booking dot com and book ASAP. Plan to spend at least three(four is better) nights in each. Travel to the next city is an entire day. I was in Italy in April/
beginning of May.

Absolutely do not try for 8 cities in only 12 days. The train rides themselves could take hours each day. Hubby and I attempted to do several spots in the french riviera and were absolutely exhausted by the travel part. Rome was my absolutely favorite spot to stay a couple days.

I am going in October for 12 days. We are doing just Florence, Venice and Rome with a day trip out of Florence to Sienna/ San G/ vineyard. I am barely finding time to do everything I want just in those cities, so I highly suggest doing less. I chose sienna etc over Pisa based on feedback in this group, but there are plenty of Pisa day trip options if you still prefer that. I have also read that Verona is highly overrated, but can also be just a couple hour train stop on your way to Venice.
You need more time in Florence and Rome than in Venice, if those end up as your big 3, which I suggest though biased. Naples and the south could be a whole other trip one day.
I saw you also asking about Vatican earlier. Too early to grab regular tickets- they’re not sold out. One way to get tickets earlier than others, though, is to book a special tour like breakfast one or bus through gardens. More expensive but available earlier and people seem to love these. We are doing bus.
Happy to answer more questions!

That's alot for 12 days. We did Naples, Almalfi, Rome and Venice with kids for 10 days and wasn't enough. (Did 3 days also in Paris before that). Few days in each city is just to little time from my experience unless you like the actual traveling place to place and rushing to see main sights just to say you've seen it and get a picture. I always cram vacations and when I do I always wish I had chill time to just roam & explore. Choose main base towns and take day trips is much easier as well as flying in and out of different airports. We flew in Naples and worked our way north by train flew out of Venice to avoid back track.
10 days? I will do 3 nights Rome, 3 Nights Florence and 3 Nights Venice.

The cities you plan to visit are not so close to each other as you would think from the map.. Choose less cities, see and enjoy more! Otherwise you will spend your time on road and packing.. Have a nice trip!!
How much does 12 days in Italy cost? Approximately

We are going next month.starting in Rome x 4nights, taking a train to Naples to Sorrento for 3 nights. We will do day trips from sorrento to Capri and the Amalfi coast .Sorrento to Florence for 3 nights. Will do a day trip to Pisa by train. You can even do Venice from Florence.From Florence to Como for 3 nights. Doing the Bernina express into Switzerland from Como and day trips to Bellagio. Then 2 nights in Milan. This gives you enough time to see everything and have some relaxing time. Good luck🙏😊

We were there for 3 weeks and it wasn’t nearly enough time. I would do 2 days in Verona and 1 in Naples and skip Milan

or me Is the most beautiful Florence and Venecia 🙂

Visit Senior Hotel Cattolica Italy. You will like it.

We've stayed all over when visiting Italy, but the one that sticks in my mind is in Bologna because we've stayed there several times. The NH De La Gare was the perfect place for us when we traveled alone and with our teen/adult children. We loved that it was just around the block from the train station, still central to everything, and they had a great breakfast to start the day. Also, you are in the perfect area if you love prosecco! That area makes Pignoletto, which is smaller bubbles and oh SO GOOD! I'm sad that I can't get it here in Florida 😢
For Milan I would suggest staying in lake como and do a day trip to Milan. Como is much more beautiful and only 1hr by train.
8 cities in 10 days is about 5 cities too many or 12+ days too few.
Did I read this right? 8 places in 10 days? Arriving and departing are not part of this, I hope. For 10 days, I’d suggest 3 max places.
Stay at each place. The best time of the day is early morning or late at night when all the tourists have gone and the streets are quiet. This is when you feel the soul of the city.
Please let us know the number of days you have and if this includes travel days.
Just go...you will find the best answer yourself:)!
If you can stay in Sorrento I highly recommend it. Loved walking the main area at night so fun and a beautiful place

You should land in Milan, then stay one night in Milan to visit at least the Duomo Square and Galleria Vittorio Emanuele with Teatro La Scala. If you like art you can choose between Palazzo Reale or Museo del Novecento exhibitions, they are amazing. The other day you can move by train to Verona, which is famous for Arena and for Juliet's house (idealized) (one day trip)- next by train Venezia, at least two days, one to wander around and the other to get into Basilica di San Marco and Palazzo Ducale. Check if you like Murano glass working and Burano village because are spectacular but are off the beaten tracks and you should spend another day there. Then you want to move to Bologna by train, ok. Bologna is a relaxing little city, count a dinner and a lunch in different typical restaurants. Choose on TripAdvisor restaurants with several top reviews by italians (when I travel I prefer the places chosen only by the natives). After lunch leave for Florence and dedicate to this city at least two days: Duomo square, Palazzo Vecchio out and in, Academia for the David, Palazzo del Bargello and of course a picture of and from Ponte Vecchio!! For Dinner Fiorentina steak with Chianti wine, no vegetarians (sorry). Pisa I would jump it to leave a bit of time to see Rome: at least the center with the most important attractions and the Roman Ruins, count again a lunch and dinner at a local trattoria. There is a famous one that I'd like to visit myself, known as the Sora Lella's after a famous Italian comic actress that owned it herself. Now it should be her nephew's. In Naples remember to eat Pizza Margherita or Marinara everywhere (it is amazing in every single pizzeria) and don't wait in line for the most famous because it's a pity to lose time in a city where pizza art is everywhere. Naples: I'd visit the Museo of San Gennaro Treasure, the Cristo Vela to, the Theatre and Maschio Angioino wandering here and there in the meantime. remember Babbá al Rum and Sfogliatella.

Too many cities for such a short stay. Pick two bases. Do day trips.

Venice, Florence, Rome if you must pick three. Assume you will be back - that’s Rick Steves’ advice.

I
Am going for 14 days that I am not even counting the travel days and I only have 3 bases and no Milan and no south , I personally would not do all these in 12 days , u do not really see much or enjoy a lot , Rome is definitely deserve at least 3-4 days , then u can base in Florence and spend 2 days there then u can visit Pisa and even add Lucca as a day trip , then u can base in Bologna and go to Venice and Verona and leave from Bologna or just have 2 base and do Venice Bologna Verona All
From Florence as the base

Beautiful hotel staff amazing 7 min walk to the duomo and center just close enough away to not be in the middle of the chaos ￼but walkable to everything
10 days and 8 cities….. not a great idea. Choose 3 at most and explore those.

Siena can be a home base for Rome, Pisa, and Florence, and is a destination in itself. Don’t forget about Assisi, too!

text: Hi there, after some quick help. Where can you get money from ATM without being charged a 13% fee? I am Australian and my card has no international transaction fees (ING), but every atm I have been to in Rome has a huge fee and a poor conversation rate. Any help in advance would be great, thank you.

comments.comment_text: Bank atm.
Only use the ones at banks wherever in Europe.

I'm with ING as well, make sure you select "don't accept conversion" or something along those lines when the conversion is displayed. This means that ING will do the conversion and decide how much money comes out of your account for the selected amount of euro, not the ATM. ING has a very good conversion rate, it part of the reason I'm with them
Go to a bank atm, there should be no fees
Get a Revolut card
Go inside the bank.

I noticed the conversion option for the 1st time at every atm when i was there in the spring. I don't remember ever seeing it in the past. Regardless, just decline the conversion and let your bank do the math... you will save big $.

There's an increasing number of ATMs not linked to banks: those are simply "selling" you money at their own service fee, without applying the intra-bank conversion fee agreed by your bank with other players of the bank circuit
Must be a bank ATM and select "don't accept conversion"!!
Get travellex card no withdrawal fees, not that's any help now. Unfortunately not any way around it, especially Au to Euro conversion it's eye watering.
Google bancomat near me
Bancomats charge no fees by law.

text:
I'm looking for your suggestions!
My daughter is leaving at the end of this month to study in Rome for fall semester at American University. I bought her a mother lode junior backpack because of all of the great reviews, however, it is huge on her (she's very petite) I have also read that you want to have a backpack that you can flip around andआणखी wear it in the front if needed on trains or buses, and this particular backpack is too big to do that. With all of this said, I'm looking for your suggestions on the best backpack for my daughter to take and be able to use throughout Europe (front and back and not too big).
Thank you!

comments.comment_text:
https://
amzn.to/3OqEZN3

My daughter used the osprey 40 liter with the optional second clip on pack. It was the biggest size allowed to still carryon for most international flights. She’s been backpacking across Europe. She’s 5’ 4”. A few small planes required to check due to weight restrictions.

Fjällräven seems to be a popular backpack with high school and college age there - I’ve seen a lot of them when I’ve been there. I haven’t tried, but I’ve read the guy who started the company did research to make backpacks more comfortable.
My daughter 5’2” 110lbs took a Patagonia 40L backhole pack with her for the summer. She had packing cubes in there to keep her sane.
Tumi brand

Several factors could determine the answer. Price, size, weight, intended use, etc.
I'd recommend going to a specialty store and trying a few out for size, fit and versatility. Then once she finds what works for her, either purchase there or browse online for one that fits her size and other requirements.
Hope she e joys her time there. Very lucky girl!!

Just don’t keep anything valuable in this backpack. Use a crossbody handbag or a belt bag instead for that stuff.

I just spent a month abroad with the non-junior size mother lode and it’s a fantastic bag. Don’t throw the baby out with the bath water when a separate handbag/belt bag is the answer here.
Tell her to buy one there. It will be better quality, less expensive and on trend.
Is the backpack all the luggage she is taking?

Am 5 ft tall and I like the Osprey backpack for hiking. You can go to a specialty store as it is good for your daughter to try on different back packs - it’s like wearing shoes, it has to be a good fit as well; especially for back support and good balance. Important to note that she cannot put valuables in her backpack.

Travelling to Europe, we have invested in anti-theft bags for the whole family - backpacks and cross body bags. They are now our go-to bags when travelling.

Travelon and Pacsafe are good brands. They have safety locks, anti-slash, with RFID compartments, etc. I would still recommend she tries them out so that it fits her properly.

If she has a 28" suitcase for the bulk of her belongs at the dorm, a large college backpack should be fine for 3-4 nights. Plus she can use the backpack for daily college classes. The Mother Load jr seems overkill for long weekend getaways. If she sticks with the ML jr, would she also have a second pack for daily classes...? Many use the ML jr as their sole travel suitcase/
luggage.

My 5’ daughter got a Baboon to the Moon pack for weekend excursions while in Italy. Not sure if you can wear it frontwards, but it seems like a good size to hold things but also not too large for her petite frame. Definitely too big for a day bag to class though.
That post was for Jill Clary Hilder

Can you bring her to a shop? I’m small and it’s good to get a fitting, not just height but shoulders etc.
I’d also suggest that she bring two bags with her to Rome and use only one for her European travel.

I highly recommend doing the after dark tour if the Doges Palace and St Marks, outstanding!

Restaurants we loved were Osteria Da Carla, Osteria Enoteca San Marco and Guna.
Hotels all booked I take it?
Visit Verona!!

Get a day / multiple day pass for the vaparetto and use it to go to Burano and Murano. Great way to move around Venice. I spent a lot of time walking. Caught vaparetto to S.Elena and walked back. Make the effort to be out and about at 6am one day and you will see a very different Venice. Some of my favourite pics were on this morning. Venice with no one around is even more stunning ❤️🇮🇹🇦🇺

if you are familiar with kayaking and want something special www.venicekayak
.com

the islands are great - apart from Murano, which is only interesting if you fancy being dragged into a glass-blowing place, a popular tourist-trap since I was there as a kid - and it´s got a couple of good authentic restaurants ( www.aquastanca.
it or "Lele il Rosso") . Burano is lovely ( try to get there early!) and easy to reach by vaporetto - best to eat is www.venissa.it on Mazzorbo - connected with Burano by a bridge. Sant´Erasmo is the vegetable garden of Venezia , you can have a look at a wineyard, eat at a streetfood stand with local products ( www.myexperient
ia.it) near the jetty or rent bicycle to explore the island there. If you´ve got time and want to get away from the tourist craze - make a trip to Chioggia - vaporetto to the Lido and the bus. Enroute you can stop for lunch at one of the nice seafood restaurant right on the waterfront on Pellestrina Island . And even in Venezia you´ll find wonderful hidden gems ( but that´s another story!) - go for "ombre e chicchetti" ( pic) and have "select" in your spritz instead of aperol!
Torcello is a lovely place to visit
Take the vaporettos everywhere. Get a pass for the length of your stay. Stay in a hotel in one of the quieter neighborhoods and go to small restaurants nearby.

Venice is not known for their food. We were disappointed, but knew that going in. We did a 2-day vaporetto pass which gives you unlimited rides and also includes the islands of Murano and Burano. Did a day trip to Verona as well, which I highly recommend. Enjoy!
We enjoyed our tour of the Doges palace, the apple streusel at La Lista, the chocolatier near the Marco Polo house, and of course, a gondola ride!

text: We will be flying into Naples Sunday morning and staying in Praiano for a week. We are going to Pompeii Thursday and I'm sure we'll venture to amalfi and Positano. We are from America, how hard is it to drive the windy roads? Anyone done it ok? We're in our 30s and drive in Boston and NYC from time to time- I feel like if you can navigate those roads you can do anything but I definitely could be wrong!

comments.comment_text: You won't be driving on the opposite side. 🙂 The windy roads of Amalfi would scare me if a bus was coming the other way but probably doable for a confident driver. There is NO WAY I would ever drive in Naples. It seems like a free for all (but somehow without much road rage). I also drive in Boston, but that's nothing compared to what Naples looked like.

I feel I'm a really confident driver but would not drive the coast, way too crowded and narrow and you miss many views and being able to look around. It is not driving on opposite side as stated above. We hired a private driver and so glad we did. Also trying to find parking spot is very hard so he was just able to drop us off and come back to pick us up and watch our luggage in meantime. Enjoy, it's so beautiful on coast. Boat ride to Capri was our favorite day out of all our trio to Italy.
Don't compare Manhatten and Boston to the Amalfi Coast. Take the ferry or a private driver from Naples to Sorrento. Then u can take ferries to Capri etc.
If you can navigate the Big Sur in CA, you can handle the most of the time. The roads are extremely narrow. Fold the passenger side mirror while navigating the Amalfi Coast

I drove to Ravello 10 years ago and thought it was fun. Extremely narrow. We hired a driver this trip in May. It was much nicer to just focus on the view.

www.amalfilimou
sinecarservice.
com

You can find videos of driving the Amalfi on YouTube- watch a couple of those and see what youthink. Nothing like NYC or Boston.
We did it in 2012, myhusband is a very calm driver with great spatial judgement and we rented the smallest car possible. Parking is not easy to find and spots are small. I gasped in shock a lot every time we went somewhere.
And as someone else said even if you decide to drive on the Amalfi coast do not drive in Naples- that was next level insanity.

Yeah, nope. Think more like Nascar/Formula 1 driving with everyone coming at you from different directions. My husband drives and is very comfortable doing it. But he's been driving these roads for years.
Finding parking will be more difficult than the driving.

Not a good idea. Driving in Italy is just different - with different expectations by other drivers, and the Amalfi coast is not the place to practice. Besides, the person driving would not be able to enjoy the view.

My time driving in Naples was limited to dropping off the car at the train station & it sucked. Sorrento is a different kind of chaos with scooters zipping around. I’ve driven 5 of the 6 countries we’ve visited over the last 8 weeks. I’ll pass in Naples & this area. Maybe rent a scooter if you want freedom to explore outside the city. Just get full coverage. 🤪

I was super scared after all I was reading but my husband insisted he would be fine driving and would rather drive here. We rented a car from Rome then stopped a few days in Latina area and made our way here yesterday. And to be honest; we got here yesterday and it was totally okay. It is a bit crazy but as long as you give way where you need, it wasn’t as awful as I thought it would be. Aside from my daughter throwing up in the car from the windy roads! Our airbnb set up parking for us, so we just drove into positano to a parking area and we won’t see our car for a few days. We don’t plan on driving around here but in and out, totally okay if you’re comfortable and confident. I will add that we tried to stop in Naples for pizza on the way here and we found that much more confusing and crazy…lol we ended up skipping the pizza!

No comparison. Hire someone else to drive who has experience with the area. Otherwise, you become a hazard to others. Plus, will miss some of the most beautiful, breathtaking views you will ever see (Positano).
Have a wonderful vacation.
We are currently in Monterosso, Cinque Terre, and loving it.
I wouldn’t. Cars actually have to back up for buses around some of the corners. Way easier to take the ferry and get a driver from town to town.

watch the youtube videos of driving in the Amalfi Coast. Also there may be some restrictions, by even/odd license plates, on when you can drive those roads. Extremely crowded in the summer and/or weekends.
View from the bus from Amalfi to Salerno…..
Go on YouTube and look for driving the Amalfi coast. We took a bus in Sicily to Castelmola. Omg only room for one vehicle. No way would I want to drive. The busses make the cars back up.

I rent a car every time I've gone since 2001 - and love driving the winding roads. There's a big difference between Italy's roads vs. Boston/NYC - and the winding road also change in elevation, and they're narrower than roads in the US. You need both hands on the wheel at all times, and full attention on driving. A small car with a manual transmission will make it more enjoyable too, IMO. And for comparison: the mountain roads in rural Colombia make the driving/roads in Italy look and feel like an American Interstate highway.
I wouldn’t it is crazy🌻

Driving in Naples is a bit of experience. Almost like you have to close your eyes and hope for the best lol Almafi itself is fine but very narrow. If you're uncomfortable with heights I would suggest to take transfer or ferry. Parking is a big issue as you cannot park in the town unless your hotel has an option for parking

I rent a car all the time but lived in Naples for 4 years. Will be there next April, where I'm staying in Ravello there is parking. I would say, for your first time stay in Maiori, from there you can take the ferry to Amalfi, Positano, Capri, Sorrento. If you want go to Ravello drive there early, be there no later than 8, you'll be able to park in the car park, go to Piazza Descivado, have a cappuccino and graffa, then walk the town, see Villa Ruffalo and don't miss Villa Cimbrone!!! Been going to Ravello for 40 years, have friends and great memories.

While we were on the roads in Amalfi vespas we’re passing between our van and the cliff or against the rocks. It was crazy! I’d be too afraid of hitting them or going over the cliff myself. Plus there’s zero parking in the cities your quoted that’s why taxis/
minibuses/vans drove people off then leave until pick up
Narrow roads, huge buses, daredevil locals, hairpin turns and scooters flying by don't make it a pleasant drive. Make sure you have no deductible, full coverage insurance.

We’ve driven the Amalfi several times. It can be a challenge but it can be done. But please don’t make the mistake of thinking the Amalfi Coast is like driving in Boston or New York City. We drive there as well and there’s simply no comparison. The Amalfi is far worse. Congestion beyond your wildest expectations occurs every day.

To drive it with less stress we like to get up very early, eat breakfast and then be out and actually ON on the coast road before 8am. Since most of the tour buses and most drivers aren’t on the road until about 10am getting this early of a start helps to avoid the worst of the congestion. And since the actual distance between towns on the Amalfi is pretty small you can be in your destination early enough to find parking and explore the town befure the elbow to elbow hordes descend. We stay in that one town, exploring, enjoying a long, leisurely lunch, shopping , taking photos, or relaxing on the beach (whatever we feel like doing) until late afternoon when the tour buses leave. Then we drive to our next destination or back to our base town when the buses and the majority of drivers are gone fur the day. This strategy helps a lot! I’d recommend it. Not only will you have less congestion on the road itself but you will have a more enjoyable time in each town before and after the masses are out in full force.

I believe there are some YouTube videos that show what driving on the Amalfi Coast is like. You might want to watch a few of those to get an idea of what to expect.
You have no idea. Better to pay drivers and take public transport. Parking is brutal.

Driving wasn't so bad. Of course my husband (who drove) does not agree and says NEVER AGAIN! Parking was a nightmare! This was in late September. I'm pretty sure you can ferry anywhere from Praiano. And nice choice of towns to stay in! It's beautiful! ENJOY!

I’ve been to Italy 3 times & driven all over. We stayed outside Amalfi & took the public bus in. I’m adventurous & it was terrifying, but kudos to the bus driver. It was really crowded & hot & we all about barfed bec of the windy roads. I would NEVER drive those roads as you will have to contend with HUGE buses on narrow curvy roads. I would either arrive by boat (but that would be from like Sorrento) or I would hire a driver. It is what I will do if I have the opportunity to go back to Amalfi. And Sorrento is awesome as well & I hear Capri is nice as well. Might be too late, but just my advice based on my experience. Also, BUY THE CAR INSURANCE 😱

I have mixed thoughts. I drove from Pienza, through Naples to Praiano in September 2019. I was mainly concerned about parking. The hotel we were at had 5-6 spaces, that in the US would hold 2 maybe 3 cars. We parked for 3 nights. I didn't have a problem, but it is very narrow and you might have to back up for the buses.

text: I’m just beginning to research a trip in 2024. If we were there for two weeks, what would be the ideal itinerary and what would be the best time frame? I was thinking September-October?

comments.comment_text: I just answered someone else with a similar question. This is a portion of my comment. I have been to Italy several times and will be returning in September. My personal suggestion is for you to spend 5-7 days in Florence which will allow time to explore beautiful Tuscany and even Cinque Terre. I would then head south to Sorrento for another 5-7 days where you could experience gorgeous Sorrento, the unbelievable Amalfi coast to include Capri, Ishia, Positano and Ravello and finally end up in Rome for 2 days before heading home. You can save a good deal of money with longer term stays at VRBOs and have the advantage of being able to do your laundry and eat simple meals like breakfast at home.
There is no "ideal" itinerary, it depends on the places you want to see. Don't try to squeeze everything in, you can always go back

Rick Steves’ Italy will provide you all the information you could ever
need!

Personally if this is your first trip to Italy I’d fly into Venice for 2 days, take a train to Florence for 4 days this would allow a guided tour of Tuscany, take train to Rome for 4 days, train to Sorrento which gives easy access to Amalfi Coast, Pompeii and then fly out of Naples. Travel safe, eat well and enjoy gelato.

It really depends on what you like to see (museums, ruins, beaches, cute small towns) there is no way to have an “ideal” vacation that fits anyone but I would say if it’s your first time hit Florence, Rome, Pompeii (even though I love Naples so much and even lived there 20 years ago I won’t recommend it since so many hate it). But seriously hard to narrow down for two weeks because there are so many amazing places in Italy. (I live in Sicily currently and love it but you need at least two weeks even here!
So glad you asked this. I’m planning 2025 Sept or October

text:
What is a reasonable amount of time for Rome, Florence, Lake District and Milan. Late April/early May 2024. I'm thinking 4 nights Rome, 6 nights Florence, 2 nights Lake District and 2 nights Milan?

Looking at flying in/out of Rome and Milan. Train to all locations with day trips to Cinque Terre and Tuscany. I would love to spend the majority ofआणखी time in Tuscany but feel like our hands are tied wanting to stick with public transportation.

We did 2 weeks in UK this year and exhausted ourselves walking 25k average steps a day 6 days in London and another 16-25k steps a day 8 days in Scotland. I do NOT want to do that again.

comments.comment_text:
I love Florence and just was back for the 4th time in May but if you have only 2 weeks, I think 3 nights would be plenty. I’d skip the Lake District this trip. You need 3-4 nights minimum. Siena is wonderful. And close. The hill towns are great.

Orvieto on your way to Florence from Rome is a great town, even if just for a stop for lunch.

Of course, we are all different. Some people really love Florence or not so much. Same with Milan. If you like Tuscany, as we do, you will love the lakes region and Cinque Terre, both accessible by rail. Again, we all have our differences, the last time we were in Florence, we were so put off with the crowds (even long "skip the line" lines) that we took a train one day to Siena. We have been to all the lakes, but our favorite one was Lake Como (Varenna as our base but Bellagio would have worked). Lake Garda a close second. Our Cinque Terre trip was based in Rapallo, with easy rail access from there to Genoa, Cinque Terre, Portavenere, Lerici, and Tellaro. And you can walk to Santa Margherita and stunning Portofino if you save a few of those steps.
I think your plan sounds good. I don’t like switching around a lot either. You can take a couple of day trips from Florence to see more of Tuscany.
I can’t get enough of Florence, so much so I go every year and have also lived there , so in my eyes stay as long as you can , go out to the out skirts as it is a wall city 🌻

What do you mean with Tuscany? Florence is in Tuscany, you want a day trip in heading west (Pisa, Lucca), slightly south (Siena, San Gimignano, Volterra, Certaldo) or at the bottom south (Montalcino, Pitigliano, Montepulciano, Asciano, Pienza)? Not to mention east like Cortona or Arezzo.
Lake district you mean Lago di Como? Because there are also Garda, Iseo, Maggiore, Orta. If you want to just go to Como (city) and its surroundings two days is enough, but if want to explore the entire lake and all the little towns without rushing two days is not enough. Not to mention if you want to see the “district”, ie other lakes.

text: Is cash still frequently accepted in Rome? In the process of figuring out how many euros to take and was wondering because many places in the UK have become card only since Covid.

comments.comment_text: we just used predominantly our revolute card and took 200 euro for tips etc

Euros are accepted, but our cards were used the bulk of the time. Sometimes Amex, always visa

A couple times I had cabs try to insist on euros, in which I insisted on the card and they put up little argument.
Everyone accepts cash.
There are no card only rule. You can use cash

I wouldn’t take a ton of cash besides tips and maybe some small tourist stalls if you want souvenirs. Most places take card now thankfully! And if a cab tried to argue with you, they are bs-ing. They are required to have working credit card machines!

But as a side note please don’t use a debit card if you are from US. Even in the US you should never use it for purchases because credit cards have easier ways to cancel charges if it’s stolen and it’s a lot more challenging when it’s your money in the bank that’s taken vs a credit card!!

I have used my iPhone nearly everywhere. If they don’t take card I go elsewhere. Far safer. Only have my phone on me (in fact left my wallet at home In Australia). My phone is attached to me with a metal wire tether and a cross body metal chain. Not carrying any bags, only my phone and a water bottle.
Yesterday it was raining at the Trevi Fountain and someone was there selling umbrellas. Someone got out their wallet to buy one, and a guy grabbed it and ran off. The Police were there and gave chase, but he was too quick and got away.
Most places prefer visa or mastercard get revolut and pay in euros through the app very easy and safer than cash
Only used a few coins in Rome for toilet at train station. Totally up to you how you divide cash and credit card payments.
Been in Italy a month. I don’t think I spent more than 50€ in cash… all Apple pay for me.
I spent 1100 euro in 14 days, I don't like using my card over seas, cash is king everywhere
Cash is king
They liked cash wherever I went in Rome. Most took cards too.
Used a card for meals, admission, trains, hotels, etc. Pretty much only used cash for minor purchases.

text:
I appreciate this group and have been trying not to add to the questions that seem to be repetitive. But here goes!

We (family of 4) will be in Italy Sept 4-9, starting in Naples and utilizing the trains to Pompeii then make our way to Venice. Because we only have so many days should I be booking our train in advance? I just don’t want to be stuckआणखी and find tickets are sold out. If they do go up in price for last minute, is it really a lot?

We prefer to wander some versus be on a tight schedule, just don’t want to be stuck with no seats on a train available and having to pay high priced taxis

comments.comment_text: I would book the Venice train as it’s a high speed one and is cheaper the further out you book, but not Pompeii….it’s regional. Have you thought about using Rome as a base instead of Naples and then doing a day trip to Pompeii?

it can also be much higher.
For example. If you find “supereconomy” rate (the cheaper) Napoli/venzia is around 60euro. “Base” (the higher) is 110euro.

Ok so the question is also if you have young kids they do a family 4 pack where 1 minor is free. I waited too long to book it and it was sold out and the prices had gotten more expensive with not too many choices a few days before I would have taken the train. It was florence to naples then local to sorrento. We just rented a car and it worked better for us. We drove to pompeii from sorrento which is where our hotel was
Get the Trainline app and you can book trains and store tickets.
Absolutely book in advance - September is still quite busy.
I never had problems buying my tickets the day of.

My husband and I are going the last 2 weeks of September. A few days ago we booked all our frecce passages with Trentitalia. We were able to secure Business class as I wanted to keep our bags closer and we were able to choose our seats. Prices vary very much on the time of day. We were able to secure some of the SuperEconomy fares too.

Venice is a long way from Naples and Pompeii and you only have 6 days. Even taking the fast trains it will take you the better part of one day to travel between the two. I would consider Rome instead of Venice due to the travel time on such a short trip.

I wouldn’t as we got caught in Sorrento,the local train was cancelled ( no reason) so we missed our fast train from Naples to Florence & we only got 40% of our money back and guess what would only put it in a European bank account and we came from Australia so lost a lot of money + I go to Italy every year so I only buy my ticket on the platform or day before if I’m staying in that city🌻

I'm just returning from Italy today, hight season, never had an issue buying 3 tickets day of travel. However, they are a lot more expensive than buying even a week out. Up to 3 times! But we needed fluid schedule so that was a trade off...
I would not try to visit more than 2 cities in the short amount of time you have. More time commuting means less time exploring.
Local trains you don’t need to book, just buy on the day , we did this everywhere round there in July

- Venice 2 days

2 days in Rome is plenty

We didn’t day trip to Cinque Terre because Florence was amazing. We only had one night in Florence with most of the first day and we left late the second day to Rome. We wish we had another day at least in Florence. We did love Venice though; not sure what so many people dislike it. 2 days was perfect though in Venice, we didn’t feel we needed more than that.
So many of you love Florence … can you please add on what u like, the key attractions. I must have missed these in my research.
I’d skip Venice and spend the time in Florence
Add a day to Florence. Visit Venice for the day.
Everyone’s different but personally I’d skip the Cinque Terre to allow more time in your other three destinations
Rome 2 Venice 3 ,Venice more pretty 🤩 than Rome for me 😍😍
Couple years ago on our Italy trip we did 3 nights Rome train to Florence for 4 night (we stayed extra day so we could take day trip/tour to Cinque Terre) beautiful! Train to Venice for 2 nights.
We have the same itinerary.. going mid November 🇮🇹
I probably would split the seven days between Rome and Florence.
I think it’s up to u whether u want to do Rome, Florence or Venice.. but drop 1 city 🙂
Swap number of days with Rome and Florence.

Unless the flights are so much cheaper that you NEED to fly in and out of Rome, you should consider flying to Venice so you don’t lose the day traveling by train.

All the cities are great in their own way. But if you can only do 7 days - I would do 2 days Rome, 3 days Florence, 2 days Venice.

Remember that travel time really takes away from your day. So you really don’t have as much time as you think in each city.

When I quickly looked up the train to cinque terre it looks like it was 2.5-3 hours each way. You want to make sure you get to see Florence while your there too.

Florence and Venice were my favorite stops in Italy. But to save travel time, transfers, lugging luggage, would you consider doing 2 nights Rome and 5 nights Florence. Then do a day trip to Cinque Terre and a day trip to Venice - maybe with a guide. That way you aren’t moving luggage, taking water taxis, checking into hotels. Etc. you get to see all the places on your list but you can do it from a home base? Just a thought.

If this is your first trip don’t skip anything. You will get a taste of it and will return for a longer stay. We did cinque terre in one day driving from Modena and it was beautiful. However since you are taking the train you will lose a lot of time. But it is doable. Might as well get your plane tickets for next year because you will return. BTW. More Florence time infact spend all your time in Florence :-)

Perfect! You can go to Via Pellicceria 3 (post office in Florence) and near there, there is a Mensa della Posta: so delicious local food restaurant.
More time in Florence. Go to Siena too

Just left Florence on my way to Venice. Florence is amazing, super clean, organised and safe. Rome’s landmarks are spectacular, but filthy streets are huge disappointment.

We just did the same trip but 2 in Florence 3 in Venice

We did this itinerary, except we didn’t go to the CT. I would skip one day of Rome and see the CT that day instead. 7 days is doable, but may feel a little rushed.
Venice 1 day Rome 4

Not enough time in Florence.

This will give you a nice taste of Italy …perfect for wanting more! I’d skip Cinque Terre and just enjoy Florence. 2 days is really only 1.5 and that’s easy to fill in any city especially Florence 😊
Florence ans Cinque Terre for two days it is not enough with the travelling too
Lose one city and spend another day in Florence.
Skip Florence. Venice is amazing.
I would just do Rome and Florence
We did this exact trip to fit as much in because we couldn't extend the trip. It was a busy trip but I'm so glad we got to see all three!
You need 4 days in Rome
YOU NEED MORE TIME IN FLORENCE

shops. Isabella was a great host!
The one I stayed in only was for 2 people. But..last trip I only used Airbnb and everywhere was great. Just really read the reviews and make sure there’s a bunch of them too
I think we just hear more about the negative but for every negative there are hundreds of positives. Look for superhosts and lots of positive reviews. Is it a guarantee? No, but nothing is...
We had no issues at all

I just got back from a two week trip rome, florence, and venice area and used airbnb for all of my stays.. I'd read a lot of reviews and communicate with the host prior to solidify that the unit has what the listing mentions (especially your must have's). We were there for the heatwave so their ac units had a difficult time keeping up (understandbly)
, our host went and bought us a fan for the unit (game changer to have). Location was priority for us however we liked staying a bit off the beaten path and within a 30/40 minute walk from sites (we stayed in the trastevere area and loved our experience there however the unit was a studio style so would not recommend for your family).
Airbnbs dont always have the same amenities (such as quality of toiletpaper, sheets, towels etc). However if you are able to compromise on these things its well worth the cost savings.
Have a wonderful trip:)
Hi!! We were a family of 8. We stayed at this beautiful Airbnb in July. Great neighborhood (Monti) and location. Fifteen min walk to Colosseum and twenty minute walk to Trevi.

We've stayed in many AirBnb's over the years, both in US and Europe. We've always had overall good experiences. We are only staying at AirBnbs for our trip next month, we are staying in four different ones. I feel pretty confident about our choices. Just make sure you read ALL of the reviews, recent and in the past. Try to figure out the general location (which is pretty easy to do, actually) and do a google street view of the area, gives you a better feel for where you'll be neighborhood-wi
se. Look at their house rules and the amenities to be sure they match your needs. Good luck with whatever you choose.
